Hi Rog, one thing I'd say is it that it certainly would help to have 
educational background in those areas.  Since neural nets and gas 
are largely considered research and development areas in the private 
sector, companies are likely to seek out people with research 
backgrounds in those areas to fill such positions.  I think there 
are a lot of industries with an interest in neural networks, but a 
lot of them fund research at universities instead of doing the 
research themselves.  On the other hand, there are a few companies 
that work specifically with neural networks or evolutionary 
computation.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Roger R. Smith" <rog_21@y...> wrote:
> Thanks Julian,
> I guess I mean in the public or private sector job
> wise. Like working for company X or government
> organization Y.
> 
> Rog
> 
> --- Julian Togelius <julian@t...> wrote:
> > Depends a little bit on what you are aiming at: do
> > you mean taking a
> > taught course, doing a PhD or getting hired as a
> > lecturer? Or do you
> > mean the private sector?
> > 
> > I did my MSc at the University of Sussex, Brighton,
> > UK. They have a
> > very strong group in the area, especially when it
> > comes to evolving
> > neural nets for autonomous agents (as opposed to
> > pure pattern
> > recognition), and a lot of interdisciplinarity -
> > people from biology,
> > philosophy and informatics really take an interest
> > in each other's
> > work. Brighton is a nice place to live as well.
> > 
> > Julian
> >
